article.title: Myriad Pictures to Distribute A Common Man
article.description:
Myriad Pictures has signed with Asia Digital Entertainment to distribute the action-thriller A Common Man , starring Ben Kingsley and Ben Cross. The film, which recently completed production in Sri Lanka, was adapted for the screen and directed by Chandran Rutnam ( The Road From Elephant Pass ).
In A Common Man , which is set in Colombo, Sri Lanka, a mysterious man (Kingsley) has planted 5 bombs in the politically-scarred city that are set to explode unless four major terrorists are immediately released from prison. When he calls in his demands to the Deputy Inspector General of the Colombo Police Department (Cross), it sets in motion an ideological and deadly confrontation between the truth and duty.

article.title: Iñárritu Eyeing DiCaprio & Penn for The Revenant
article.description:
Deadline is reporting that director Alejandro González-Iñárritu ( Babel ) is hoping to cast Leonardo DiCaprio and Sean Penn as the two leads in his adaptation of Michael Punke's revenge novel The Revenant , and that both actors have already met with the filmmaker with hopes to start shooting in the fall of 2012.
Set in the 1820s, DiCaprio would play Hugh Glass, a man bent on revenge after being mauled by a bear on a fur trapping expedition, then robbed and abandoned by the two men left behind to help him. One of those men would be played by Penn if everything works out. The film is being produced by New Regency to be distributed by 20th Century Fox.
Many other names have been rumored to adapt Punke's novel in the last few years including director John Hillcoat ( The Road )...

article.title: Benicio Del Toro Up for Star Trek Sequel
article.description:
J.J. Abrams' untitled Star Trek sequel may have found its villain. Variety reports that, while nothing is yet official, Benicio Del Toro is expected to be offered the role imminently.
Famous for his secrecy, Abrams has reportedly not yet revealed even to the actor what the role will be, though production is expected to begin this January.
Chris Pine, Zachary Quinto, Zoe Saldana, Karl Urban, Simon Pegg, John Cho and Anton Yelchin are expected to all reprise their roles as members of the Enterprise crew with Abrams back in the director's chair and a script again from Roberto Orci and Alex Kurtzman.

article.description:

article.title: Tower Heist Review
article.description:
While the promotional images for Tower Heist may suggest that Eddie Murphy and Ben Stiller share the spotlight in a wacky buddy comedy, they are only wishful thinking. Murphy is not the star, and the product itself is a strange hodgepodge of tones. Yet once the lengthy set up is complete and the cast of inexperienced robbers are finally assembled, the flick eventually manages to steal a few laughs.

Manhattan high-rise staff manager Josh Kovacs (Stiller) and his crew of doormen, maids and concierges (comprised of an impressive cast, including Casey Affleck, Michael Peña and Precious actress Gabourey Sidibe) spend their days catering to the whims of their wealthy tenants, especially billionaire Arthur Shaw (Alan Alda). After Shaw is arrested for fraud, Kovaks learns the magnate has lost every employee’s pension, and when Kovacs discovers the white collar crook may have a secret stash in his condo, the enraged lead plots a heist. Way in over his head, Kovacs enlists the help of his closest work associates, such as a small-time thief named Slide (Murphy) and bankrupted resident turned squatter Mr. Fitzhugh (Matthew Broderick).

Stiller doesn’t have much to do here but play the straight man, even courting a possible romance in a subplot with a special agent (Tea Leoni) assigned to the case. While everything Kovacs does is necessary to move the plot forward, it’s not particularly amusing and their relationship feels forced. Truthfully, the film’s first half seems to teeter tonally between half-hearted comedy and serious drama, as captured by director Brett Ratner (the Rush Hour series, X-Men: The Last Stand).  One character’s attempted suicide is jarringly dark and feels like a heavy-handed effort to gain audience sympathy, even if the plot point becomes necessary later.  Thankfully, the laughs finally arrive as the caper intensifies.

Co-writer Ted Griffin also wrote Ocean’s 11, and the connection is obvious. At times, Ratner’s Heist resembles an abandoned Ocean’s sequel; one with a cast of fools subbing in for pros (except Affleck, who plays himself). The screenplay adds enough double crosses and complications to keep viewers on their toes, and the heist itself is fun and surprisingly exciting. Several different elements, including distracting staff, knocking out guards, safe cracking and carjacking are handsomely photographed by cinematographer Dante Spinotti (L.A. Confidential, Heat), then dynamically edited with plenty of energy.

Murphy fans will be pleased to see the actor also showing more liveliness on screen, if not exactly channelling his erratic persona from the early ’80s. From the moment Slide is bailed out of prison, the movie jolts to life. The thief insists on practice sessions, like stealing random items from a shopping mall and picking locks while freezing on a rooftop. The group’s bickering becomes wittier and punchlines land faster and funnier. Broderick also stands out, milking his timid, sad sack character for maximum humor.

Tower Heist is not a comedy classic or even one of the year’s funniest, but, after a rough start, the movie builds up some momentum and ends strongly. This hustle certainly could have used more of Murphy, but in the end it still manages (if only just barely) to pull it off.

3 out of 5

article.title: A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas Review
article.description:
Halloween may have only just passed, but like a display in a department store, the holiday season hype has begun.

A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas attempts to deliver raunchy Yuletide hilarity in the vein of Bad Santa, but this second sequel falls well short of the mark. It’s higly unlikely anyone will remember this movie by Thanksgiving, let alone the end of December.

In the years since their previous adventure, Harold (John Cho) has distanced himself from best pal Kumar (Kal Penn). Because while Kumar still lives in the same apartment, in the same perpetually stoned state, his successful buddy Harold has moved into a fancy house with wife Maria (Paula Garcés).

When Maria’s intimidating father (an amusing Danny Trejo) arrives for a visit with the rest of the family, Harold takes on the task of decorating a specially-grown fir tree while the others attend Christmas Mass. Of course, Kumar drops by and accidentally burns the tree down. The pair desperately attempt to hunt down a replacement fir before the family returns, and rekindle their friendship in the process.

Misfortunes inevitably follow and soon they’re on the run from a Ukrainian mobster (Elias Koteas), who mistakes them for rapists, and a Wafflebot that fires skin-melting grills at anyone who prefers pancakes. They also encounter an infant that accidentally ingests marijuana, cocaine and numerous other illicit substances and becomes hyperactive as a result. If this sounds more stale than side-splitting, you would be right.

This time out, the humor isn’t as focused on the character’s wild interactions – it’s about throwing in random, bizarre, and shocking sight gags that don’t have the impact they once did. In between, cameos reintroduce characters from previous films, including series regular Neil Patrick Harris as “himself.” It’s nice to see them, but they don’t add much to the main narrative. Additionally, self-referential nods to White Castle and the personal lives of the stars (in particular, Penn’s stint as a White House staffer) become tedious.

Even the big skits feel like missed opportunities. While attempting to dodge Maria’s family, the pair unintentionally crash a rehearsal for a musical number in a television special. They don’t end up being thrown in front of a real crowd or live TV, or find themselves being forced to improvise. Instead, they simply perform with relative ease as the number progresses smoothly. The situations just aren’t as memorable.

At least the filmmakers have chosen to milk the third dimension for everything its worth. Everything that can be hurled into the audience is, including bong smoke and shattered glass. The highlight (and one of the few laughs) involves the gruesome 3D egging of a supporting character. Without the 3D, there is little else to recommend.

Penn and Cho are talented and still manage a few funny offhanded observations, but for the most part A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas gives them little to work with. At the end of a scene, NPH casually states, “See you in the fourth one!” One hopes all involved walk away from the franchise before things get any worse.

2 out of 5

article.title: ‘The Last Days on Mars’ is Zombies in Space
article.description:
At this week’s American Film Market, Focus Features introduced plans to make The Last Days of Mars, a futuristic space thriller set on the surface of Mars to be directed by Irish filmmaker Ruairi Robinson in early 2012.

Robinson was nominated for an Oscar for his short film Fifty Percent Grey and was briefly considered for Warner Bros’ live-action Akira remake, in one of many iterations.

The script, written by Clive Dawson, centers on an eight-man crew wrapping up the first manned mission to Mars in 2036.  It’s day 179, the final day before the spaceship Aurora arrives to relieve them, when their paleontologist makes a monumental discovery at Site 9.  Microscopic signs of life.  Then he promptly falls in the pit, dies, and is reanimated as the walking, chasing, attacking undead.  The crew dwindles in the descending hours as they become infected themselves.

The plot is sort of John Carpenter’s Ghosts of Mars — only zombie astronauts instead of possessed miners and hopefully less Ice Cube — meets Carpenter’s beloved The Thing.  More importantly, it’s a vast improvement over other, recent space thriller scripts, like the Weinstein Company’s lunar “found footage” dud Apollo 18 (spider rocks!), which won(?) the race to the screen over the similarly terrible Dark Moon (lizard people!).

For starters, there are eight characters (not two or three), and they (for the most part) have distinct personalities.  Plus Dawson’s script focuses on building suspense and terror, not distracting gimmicks and eye-rolling conspiracy theories.  Effective use of slow, automated airlocks delay the inevitable attacks.  Some radar blips (a la Aliens) track their movement.  A countdown clock reminds you of the approaching Aurora.  Solid script.  With Robinson’s raw talent and the right cast, this “zombies in space” movie could definitely work.

article.title: Video: James Bond 23 Officially Titled ‘Skyfall’
article.description:
Calling it “the worst kept secret in London,” Michael G. Wilson, producer of the twenty-third James Bond movie, revealed the sequel’s official title: Skyfall.  The new name was old news though, when it slipped out last month after a brand protection company started buying up web domain names (e.g. skyfall-movie.com on behalf of Sony Pictures.

But the title’s early release didn’t rain on Sony’s parade, specifically a classy press conference on Thursday to make the name official and trot out their star-studded cast.

Director Sam Mendes introduced each one.  Daniel Craig is returning as Bond, his third as 007.  Judi Dench is back as M.  Javier Bardem was confirmed as “the villain of the piece.” French actress Berenice Malohe is playing Severine, one of the “Bond ladies.” The other is Naomie Harris, who will play a field agent named Eve — not Moneypenny as rumored — and has already been training for two months. Ben Wishaw is playing a part Mendes says he “can’t tell you about.”  Albert Finney is… also playing an undisclosed part.  And, again in a secret role, Ralph Fiennes.

Thursday’s press conference coincided with the launch of the film’s official Facebook page and a Twitter account, @007. From that Twitter accounts comes the official synopsis:

Bond’s loyalty to M is tested as her past comes back to haunt her. As MI6 comes under attack, 007 must track down and destroy the threat, no matter how personal the cost.

The title has an “emotional context which will be revealed in the film,” Wilson said, though elaboration was clearly out of the question all around.

It was essentially a formal kick-off announcement for the months-long production, but Mendes used it to set the record straight on a few items.  Almost defensively he insisted, “I think [Skyfall] has all the elements of a classic Bond movie.  Including, to quell any rumors, a lot of action.”  He continued, proudly confirming the production’s international locations.  ”Bond’s journey takes him to” London (starting Monday), China (Shanghai and elsewhere), Turkey (Istanbul and “other parts”), and Scotland (where they will reportedly film an “explosive” climax at Duntrune Castle). “Lots of surprises,” Mendes added later.

The event marked the 50th anniversary of when Sean Connery was announced as James Bond, prior to the release of Dr. No. When Skyfall is released on October 26 — in the UK. The U.S. will have to wait until Nov. 9 — it will be the series’ golden (gun) anniversary.

Digital Spy uploaded the entire 30-minute press conference, in case you’re interested in seeing it all unfold for yourself:

article.title: Bale, Blanchett Paired for Two New Malick Films
article.description:
Reclusive filmmaker Terrence Malick is suddenly becoming prolific.  Something about the long, arduous ordeal to create The Tree of Life, his Palm d’Or winning 2011 film conceived in the late ’70s, has stirred Malick back to work.  He now has four projects in various stages of development, which is out of character for the Austin, Texas-based director who typically takes years off between films, including a decade between 1978’s Days of Heaven and 1998’s The Thin Red Line.

In August, Malick said he was “rushing towards a mix” on his next movie, an untitled drama often referred to as The Burial.  The LA Times has more this week, including a plot synopsis that explains the previously reported “international love triangle.”  Ben Affleck plays a philanderer who travels to Paris where he has a “hot-and-heavy” affair with a European woman (Olga Kurylenko).  The two return home to Oklahoma, where he marries her for visa reasons, but he rekindles his romance with a former girlfriend (Rachel McAdams).  Javier Bardem plays a priest he seeks for advice.  Amanda Peet and Michael Sheen have also been rumored, and Tree of Life’s breakout star Jessica Chastain is said to play a small role.

Malick is “rushing” the mix despite reportedly turning down distribution offers and his meticulousness in the editing room.  (If you’re a Tree of Life fan, read this account of his extraordinary process from one of the editors.)  It seems Malick is eager to clear his schedule for his next two films, Lawless and Knight of Cups, both announced this week.

The back-to-back productions will shoot next year and The New World’s Christian Bale, who was replaced by Affleck on the previous film due to scheduling conflicts, and world-class actress Cate Blanchett, according to The Playlist.  Malick and Bale were at the Austin City Limits music festival last month shooting among the revelers, and, as it turns out, those shots were to help the actor get into character for Lawless.  Ryan Gosling is also on board, as well as Rooney Mara (the new Lisbeth Salander in Fincher’s Girl with the Dragon Tattoo) and relative newcomer Haley Bennett.  Otherwise there’s little known about the film.

Knight of Cups is also under the same shroud of secrecy.  (Maybe it’s about tarot cards?)  It will feature Bale and Blanchett again, along with Aussie actress Isabel Lucas.

The last film is an IMAX production called Voyage of Time that would use footage shot during the process of making Tree of Life.  Brad Pitt has been rumored as its narrator, though again it’s unclear how far along he is with the documentary.

article.title: Joel Edgerton Has Arrived, Offered ‘300′ Sequel
article.description:
Hollywood’s newest leading actor, Joel Edgerton, has arrived.  Two major offers this week solidify the Aussie’s status in the Hollywood elite, even if they aren’t the most exciting movies.

The first is the lead in Warner Bros’ 300: Battle of Artemisia, the follow-up to the studio’s 2006 sword-and-sandal epic featuring Gerard Butler.  Zack Snyder, who directed the original, wrote the prequel (formerly titled Xerxes) from another, unpublished Frank Miller graphic novel and will produce, but is currently tied up with Superman then other projects.  Naom Murro (Smart People) will direct instead.

Vulture reports if a deal is reached, Edgerton will go shirtless again to play Themosticles, the conniving leader of the Greek army who formed their navy and defeated the Persians.  It will be a separate timeline from the first, where King Leonidas (Butler) lead 300 Spartans against Xerxes.  In the pre-sequel(?), the action begins 10 years in the past, as Xerxes searches for godhood, and Themosticles becomes a great Greek warrior in the lead up to their clash in 480 B.C.

Meanwhile, Edgerton also has an offer from WB to star in The Man from U.N.C.L.E., an ill-advised revival of a spy series in the ’60s.  At least Steven Soderbergh is directing, if he doesn’t retire first.  Edgerton would play Ilya, the Russian spy previously played by David McCallum.  George Clooney was attached before, but dropped out.  The Hangover lead Bradley Cooper is considering the opposite part, Napoleon Solo, though his plate seems stacked inexplicably high at the moment.

Hollywood stardom continues to be arbitrary and unpredictable, but from what we’ve seen so far Edgerton is one of the good ones.  This all happened due to his supporting role in the little-seen Aussie thriller Animal Kingdom in 2010.  He was down to the final two in The Bourne Legacy casting.  He was the second best thing about The Thing — the first was, without a doubt, Mary Elizabeth Winstead — though that’s not saying much for the lackluster remake.  He crushed his role in Warrior, looking and acting the extremely physical part (and making it look easy).  Next he’s lined up as Tom in Baz Luhrmann’s The Great Gatsby among a star-studded cast that includes Leo DiCaprio and “it” actress Carey Mulligan.

With casting still in the early stages, 300: Battle of Artemisia doesn’t have a start date yet.  But if I had to guess, at this rate, the prequel could be in theaters by March 2013, seven years after the original.

article.title: De Niro, Travolta to Face Off in ‘Killing Season’
article.description:
Robert De Niro and John Travolta will finally go mano-a-mano this January while filming Killing Season, a thriller set in the Appalachian Mountains to be directed by Mark Steven Johnson (Daredevil, Ghost Rider).  Despite Johnson’s previous credits — and wow, are they bad — this could be a tense action-y duel between two Hollywood veterans.

De Niro plays an American military vet who lives in seclusion in the wooded mountains.  There he hunts in peace, until he’s treated to a rare visit from a mysterious traveler (Travolta) who is really a Serbian soldier looking to settle an old score.

Snow White and the Huntsman screenwriter Evan Doughtery wrote the original script, which made the 2008 “Black List”, an annual compilation of Hollywood’s “most liked” unproduced screenplays.  Though it was originally called Shrapnel, set in the 1970s against the backdrop of the Vietnam War, and the battle was between an American with a piece of metal buried in his leg and a former Nazi officer.  Die Hard director John McTiernan was previously attached, but went to prison shortly thereafter due to his involvement in the Anthony Pellicano wire-tapping case.

With spotty track records throughout this production, this could wind up being an average action flick (appropriate for Nu Image/Millennium).  But Dougherty’s script has potential for a deeper dive into old wounds and a dangerous game of cat and mouse.

article.title: ‘Burt Wonderstone’ Details: Carell, Carrey, Magic
article.description:
New Line is moving forward on Burt Wonderstone, a comedy about a down-and-out Las Vegas magician.  Steve Carell has been attached to star for over a year now, but the rest of the casting is quickly ramping up as the production aims for a potential January 2012 start date.  ”30 Rock” director Don Scardino will run the show for his first major studio film.

That schedule is reportedly perfect for Steve Buscemi, who is currently between seasons on “Boardwalk Empire.”  Variety reports Buscemi is in talks to play Anton Lovecraft, Burt’s assistant since they were children, when they were turning “tricks” to impress girls and baffle bullies.  But, in the present, Burt (Carell) is caught up in his own fame, as one half of the number one magic act in the world, and his selfishness tears the two “magical friends” apart.  When Anton is injured performing the “hotbox” trick (it’s basically just staying in a glass box for days), the two go their separate ways.  Anton to the Far East, where he gifts magic sets to starving children, and Burt Wonderstone to the worst gig imaginable (a nursing home), where he rediscovers his love of magic.

After some speculation (and New Line’s attempts to bag Sacha Baron Cohen), Jim Carrey boarded the cast last month.  He will play Steve Haines, their increasingly popular rival and a “street magician” (in the vein of Criss Angel) who performs elaborate, impossible stunts.  For example, his show “Steve Haines: Brain Rapist” features him being punched in the face, then producing the man’s card from a cut in his bruised cheek.  Burt and Anton’s “hotbox” idea is in response to audience attention shifting to Haines’ oddities.  Carrey guested on NBC’s “The Office” following Carell’s departure.  (The show hasn’t been the same since.)

An old draft played this out as a broad comedy with plenty of wacky one-ups-manship.  Imagine one producing a live puppy from a balloon animal, then the other crushing the puppy into nothing.  It’s absolutely ridiculous, but for a movie that combines the comedic talents of Carell, Carrey, and Buscemi, I wouldn’t have it any other way.

James Gandolfini will play Burt and Anton’s boss, Vegas casino owner Doug Munny.  This will, of course, be more mobster typecasting for the once versatile Gandolfini.

This leaves the role of Nicole, the duo’s lovely assistant who becomes a bit of a love interest for Burt.  Olivia Wilde has been reported in some of the trades, but Deadline insists others are still in the mix, including comedienne Sarah Silverman, the very funny Judy Greer, and possibly Jessica Biel.

Chad Kultgen and Tyler Mitchell wrote the original story.  Former “Freak and Geeks” actor John Francis Daley and his Horrible Bosses writing partner Jonathan Goldstein did revisions.  Surprisingly, Jason Reitman did some script doctor work on it, according to THR.

Summit Entertainment is nearly underway on their own magic-themed movie.  Now You See Me is a heist thriller that centers on a criminal investigation into an all-star magic act called “The Four Horsemen.”  The team uses magic to distract audiences and authorities while they pull off various large-scale robberies.  Think Thomas Crown Affair in terms of tone.  Jesse Eisenberg, Woody Harrelson, Morgan Freeman, Michael Caine, and Mark Ruffalo will star.  The two movies could clash in 2013, depending on how they’re scheduled, and we could see a repeat of magical 2006 when The Illusionist took on The Prestige.

article.title: In Time Review
article.description:
The concept behind In Time is intriguing and relevant – regular folk revolt against the upper classes and a crooked system controlling the destinies of the poor – yet director Andrew Niccol (Gattaca) doesn’t quite hit the target with this effort.  It is unlikely viewers will be demanding their two hours back, but they may not be satisfied with the time spent either.

The opening scenes introduce the audience to a world in which people are genetically engineered to age naturally until they reach their twenty-fifth birthday.  From then on, time becomes the most important (and only) currency.  Months and years are traded to each citizen’s personal clock for services rendered, which can be spent on basic necessities like rent or material goods. In this dystopia, when the clock embedded in  your forearm ticks down to zero, life ends.

Will (Justin Timberlake) resides in the slums of the city, living from minute to minute. After encountering a suicidal stranger, he is unexpectedly gifted over one hundred free years, as well as the valuable information that those in power are raising prices (thus shortening lives) to avoid overpopulation. Will vows to take them down while avoiding a determined “Timekeeper” cop, Leon (Cillian Murphy), and local mobster named Fortis (Alex Pettyfer). Along the way, Will kidnaps bored socialite Sylvia Weis (Amanda Seyfried) who, of course, falls for the rebel and joins the cause against her father Philippe (”Mad Men” actor Vincent Kartheiser), the man responsible for the whole arm-countdown-watch-thingee technology.

Visually, the film is impressive. The art direction and production design echoes a film noir style pleasing to the eye. Plus there are some amusing gags involving the introductions of several generations of family who look identical, as well as confusion from characters in determining age.  For example, Olivia Wilde, 27, plays the mother of Timberlake, 30.

Disappointingly, it seems as if Niccol had so many ideas and avenues to pursue from this ripe concept that he couldn’t commit to just one. There are elements of a revenge drama, chase movie, romance, and political satire bundled into the film, which constantly switches gears with abandon, creating numerous plot holes and eventually alienating its audience.

The characters of Will and Sylvia quickly morph from fugitives to bank robbers, a la Bonnie and Clyde, and start raiding unguarded institutions with ridiculous ease. In one surprise confrontation, a character desperately lunges for a weapon before being taken hostage, but later uses a concealed version of the same item to escape. These leaps in logic taint what are otherwise suspenseful action sequences.

While the cast members are all capable performers, several come across as too flat and mannered. Given their predicament, it’s an odd way to direct them. Pettyfer seems especially miscast as one of the least intimidating mobsters in recent film history. Worst of all, there is no chemistry between Will and Sylvia, rendering the film’s most important core relationship relatively static.

In Time operates from a fascinating concept and scores some good individual moments, but it never quite excites or engages. If anything, some viewers might find the seconds ticking by more slowly than they had hoped.

2.5 out of 5

article.title: More Dark Knight Rises pics leak online
article.description:
Another day, another glut of photos leaked from the set of The Dark Knight Rises, which was filming in New York this weekend. This time, we’re treated a high-speed chase conducted on motorcycles, a hi-tech-looking explosive of some description and what just might be the Batcopter.

Whilst the explosive (if that is indeed what it is) looks a bit like a relic from one of the Joel Schumacher movies, the ‘copter looks suitably sleek and menacing as it hovers over Gotham’s streets.

Take a look at the gallery below, courtesy of SuperHeroHype, and see what you make of it.

article.title: Michael Shannon talks General Zod costume
article.description:
Following hot on the heels of some leaked snaps of Henry Cavill on the set of Man Of Steel come a few tidbits from Michael Shannon, who’s been talking to Entertainment Weekly about General Zod and what he’ll be wearing.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, the billowing capes and parachute pants of yesteryear have become a thing of the past, with Shannon explaining that today’s costumes are slightly less forgiving. “Everything's skin-tight,” laughs the star. “The flowy costumes don't really... that's not the style nowadays!"

When asked whether he has a full-on Krypton costume, Shannon’s answer was intriguing. “There’s two different modes,” he explains. “There’s something that I have to wear a motion-capture suit for, because if I actually wore it, I wouldn’t be able to move.”

“It’s a very big… thing. I actually don’t know what it’s going to look like, I just know that it’s very cumbersome. There’s another thing that I wear that’s an actual costume. It’s pretty simple. There’s no paisley or anything.”

And as well as donning the mo-cap, Shannon has apparently been doing his homework on the world of which he is now a key element.

“I don’t read the comic book,” he admits, “although when I got the job, they sent me a giant DC Comics book that weighs about a ton. It’s got the whole history of DC in it. It’s fascinating, actually. I looked at it with my daughter. She’s really fascinated by it.”

Man Of Steel opens Stateside on 14 June 2013.

article.title: Michael Caine joins Now You See Me
article.description:
Louis Leterrier’s upcoming heist thriller Now You See Me has added a touch of Oscar-winning gravitas to proceedings with the announcement that Michael Caine has joined what was already an impressive ensemble cast.

The film follows a crack team of FBI agents attempting to bring down a group of flamboyant magicians, who use their performances to pull off a series of outrageous bank heists.

According to The Playlist, Caine will take on the role of Arthur Tressler, the magicians’ sponsor. We’re envisaging something along the lines of his performance in The Prestige, with a dash more twinkly-eyed mischief thrown in for good measure.

Caine becomes the latest member of a thoroughly stellar cast including Mark Ruffalo, Jesse Eisenberg, Morgan Freeman, Isla Fisher, Melanie Laurent, Woody Harrelson. With that lineup, one thing the film shouldn’t lack for is star power.

Written as a collaborative effort between newcomer Edward Ricourt and Prince Of Persia scribe Boaz Yakin, Now You See Me will arrive in US screens on 18 January 2013.

article.title: Mickey Rourke talks Sin City 2
article.description:
Comic book fans the world over will have found their ears pricking at the news that Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller are planning to include the story Just Another Saturday Night in the long-awaited sequel to Sin City.

Involving three of the key players from the first film in the form of Hartigan (Bruce Willis), Nancy (Jessica Alba) and Marv (Mickey Rourke), it would be a popular choice, provided the original talent could be persuaded to return.

Just Another Saturday Night follows Marv's movements on the same night that Nancy and Hartigan are reunited, providing a storyline that runs in tandem with the events of the first movie's final third. Mickey Rourke is aware of proceedings and recently spoke to Comingsoon.net about the chances of a return for big Marv.

“It depends,” laughed the Wrestler star. “It depends on how bad they want me, you feel me? I did [like the character], but I'm claustrophobic, so the hours of makeup… you have to keep it on for about 13 or 14 hours a day. It's latex and glue and that stuff gets my eyes all red.”

It also got in the way of the star’s social life last time around. “I remember I picked up some chick at a bar in Texas one night and invited her to the set to have lunch at the lunch break," says Rourke. "I couldn't take the shit off. Fuck it, I never saw her again.”

That said, the character is at least one that Rourke would be interested in revisiting, which is more than can be said for Whiplash, the villain he played in Iron Man 2.

“I try to find the moments where [the villain is] not that cliched, evil bad guy," he explains. "I had it on Iron Man and they won. It was going to work for Marvel and them breaking [Jon] Favreau's balls and wanting just a one-dimensional villain. The performance and all the things that I tried to bring to it ended up on the fucking floor."

Word of warning then Mr. Rodriguez. If you do persuade Mickey Rourke to don the latex for a second time, make sure he gets lots of nice, juicy characterisation to play with. And the odd lunch break out of character might help as well…

article.title: Logan’s Run gets new screenwriter
article.description: Today it was announced that Logan’s Run, which is set to begin filming next year, has hired a new writer. Andrew Baldwin, who penned 2008 Black List script The West Is Dead, has been brought onto the project to redraft the current script. Ryan Gosling has already been confirmed to play Michael York’s character Logan. Danish filmmaker Nicolas Winding Refn will occupy the director’s chair. The pair previously collaborated on hit pulp-thriller Drive, and are set to work together again on Bangkok Thai-boxing drama Only God Forgives. Alex Garland (28 Days Later, Sunshine) and Will Beall (Gangster Squad) have both already contributed to the current script.  As of yet, the film has no provisional release date, though production is unlikely to get underway until Only God Forgives has wrapped.

article.title: Bill Murray joins Charlie Sheen on Roman Coppola’s Charles Swan
article.description: After collaborating with Sofia on Lost In Translation, Billy Murray has again teamed up with the Coppola family, this time for comedy Charles Swan. Roman Coppola, son of the legendary Francis Ford Coppola, has written the screenplay and will also direct. An eclectic cast has already been announced: Jason Schwartzman, Aubrey Plaza and tiger blood himself Charlie Sheen, who is set to make a career comeback in the film, have all been announced. Now Murray has been added, as well as Final Destination 3 star Mary Elizabeth Winstead. The full title of the picture is A Glimpse Inside The Mind Of Charles Swan III. The synopsis reads below… “Sheen stars as the title character, a successful graphic designer whose fame, money and charm have made him irresistible to women.”  “When his girlfriend breaks up with him, his life swirls into a downward spiral of doubt, confusion and reflection.” “Through delirious fantasies involving his many failed romances, he begins the hard road of self-evaluation to come to terms with life without her.” Sounds like a testing role for Charlie Sheen, who is almost completely foreign to fame, money, women and downward spirals. The film is scheduled for an unspecified 2012 release date.

article.title: Trailer for weird French horror Livid online
article.description:
Julien Maury and Alexandre Bustillo directors of brutal slasher Inside, have revealed a French-Language trailer for their new film, Livid.
As a special Halloween treat we have the trailer here, waiting for you to sink your teeth in to. 

Dimension Films are backing the new ‘horror fairytale’, which is set for theatrical release next year.

Livid is set on Halloween night, where three unaware youths break into a desolate house in the search for an old woman’s treasure.

“At night, they get into the house, which reveals itself to be increasingly peculiar. Their hunt for Mrs Jessel’s treasure leads them into a horrifying supernatural series of events that will change Lucy forever..."

The project will also see the return of Inside actress, Beatrice Dalle. Other billed cast include Jeremy Kapone, Catherine Jacob, Felix Moati and Chloe Coulloud.

Livid has been compared to the works of Dario Argento and Guillermo del Toro, which sounds like a pretty perfect combination to us.

Watch the trailer below and tell us what you think!

article.title: James Mangold discusses Wolverine
article.description:
Ah The Wolverine… if ever there were a film to file under the heading “Development Hell”, the long-awaited sequel to X-Men Origins would surely be it. However, things do appear to be moving again, with Walk The Line director James Mangold having discussed his vision for the project. And whilst we’re loathe to get too excited about this just yet, we have to admit, his ideas sound great.

“The fact that half of the characters in this movie speak Japanese,” explained Mangold to The Playlist, “[means] this is like a foreign-language superhero movie that’s as much a drama and a detective story and a film noir with high-octane action, as it is anything like a conventional tentpole film.”

"I think part of the reason I’m doing this picture,” he continues, “[is] because it isn’t to me a conventional superhero movie. It isn’t an origin story, so I’m freed from that burden, and it also isn’t a save-the-world movie, which most of them are."

“I actually think it has more in common with The Outlaw Josey Wales and Chinatown, than the conventional, ‘will Wolverine and his compatriots save the world from this thermonuclear device’ question," explains the director. "This movie is much more an intense psychological and action-packed character piece, that’s much more about Logan getting lost in this very unique and insulated world of Japanese culture, gangster culture, and ninja culture.

“The fighting is going to be unique because it’s all influenced by Japanese martial arts.”

Not that Mangold didn’t initially have reservations about attaching himself to what has been a thoroughly fraught production.

“I spoke to Darren a bit about it before I ended up taking it on,” he admits. “When Darren stepped off, I was in the middle of doing a lot of other things, and when it was brought up to me, I actually didn’t even consider it for the very reasons you’re talking about… I could hear all of the media swirl about it.”

“Several months went by and I hadn’t even really read it, [but] I kind of took it in [when] a lot of that hand-wringing had kind of died down,” he says. “What I saw was some really promising material, and to me an interesting character played by a great friend of mine who’s a terrific actor, Hugh Jackman.”

Since then, Mangold has been hard at work re-writing Chris McQuarrie’s original script, collaborating with Die Hard 4 scribbler Mark Bomback to tell the story he wants to tell.

“Mark Bomback and myself have done a tremendous amount of writing on the movie,” says Mangold. “There’s not a page that hasn’t been worked and reworked and rethought and story-boarded.”

Much as we hate to admit it, Mangold’s got us excited about this one for what must be the umpteenth time. Let’s just hope the studio don’t pull the rug out this time around… get it made Fox!

article.title: Eddie Murphy writing alien comedy
article.description:
Having recently announced an intention to turn his back upon family comedies, Eddie Murphy has revealed he’s currently working on writing his next starring vehicle himself. And apparently, it’s a comedy involving aliens.

Yes, Pluto Nash fans, your ship has finally come in, as Murphy seems determined to to take another run at creating an extra-terrestrial gag-fest. Only this time, he’ll be writing it as more of an ensemble piece.

“I still want to do something like that,” Murphy told Rolling Stone. “I have this idea called Jamal and Tyrell and Omar and Brick and Michael’s Wack-Ass Weekend about this group of guys who get abducted by aliens on the way to the fights. I’m writing that now.”

To be honest, the title alone has us quaking in our boots, but it sounds as though Murphy has at least got some A-list names in mind for his cast. His current film Tower Heist was originally planned as a joint venture between Murphy, Dave Chapelle, Chris Rock, Martin Lawrence and Tracey Morgan. With five names lined up for the aforementioned Wack-Ass Weekend, could these be the five gents we see occupying the starring roles?

Perhaps we’ll learn more during the run-up to the Oscars, which Murphy will of course be hosting. In the meantime, you’ll just have to dust off that Alien Autopsy DVD and hope for the best…

article.title: Kirsten Dunst joining Cities
article.description:
Elizabethtown co-stars Kirsten Dunst and Orlando Bloom are set to reunite for Roger Donaldson’s upcoming financial thriller Cities, once again playing a young couple in love.

With the film set across a trio of global locales, Dunst and Bloom will feature in the London-based segment, as a pair of first-time-buyers looking to get a foot on the property ladder. Given that this is a film about economic strife and white-collar crime, we don’t fancy their chances much.

Clive Owen has already signed on to the project, and will star as a hedge fund manager in New York whose primary appetites for sex and cash know no bounds. He’s joined by Anil Kapoor, who plays a crooked Mumbai cop involved in a property scam of his own.

Naturally, the three plot strands will interweave as one character’s actions have knock-on consequences for the next. Glenn Wilhilde, one-time producer on TV’s The Royle Family, has written the script.

“Cities is very much a movie for our time,” says Donaldson in the official PR burble. “The subjects of greed and money and their impact on our everyday lives surround us constantly and Cities is a movie that will explore this in a dramatic way with tension and excitement at every turn.”

The project has begun filming, with a 2012 release date currently on the cards. Meanwhile, Donaldson’s next film, the Nic Cage thriller Justice, arrives in UK cinemas in a few weeks' time.

article.title: Johnny Depp gets Golden Globes revenge on Ricky Gervais
article.description: Johnny Depp finally has some payback over comments Ricky Gervais made at the Golden Globes last year about his film The Tourist.  It's not quite the media spat you might expect though, as Depp's jibes feature on Gervais' new comedy series Life's Too Short.  Warwick Davis stars in the show as the head of a talent agency run exclusively for smaller actors.  Depp appears as a guest star and you can get a taste of his revenge below.

article.title: Puss In Boots tops US box office
article.description:
Despite lacking the titular S-word of its predecessors, Dreamworks Animation’s Puss In Boots still performed strongly on its opening weekend, with a $34 million take putting it top of the US box office.

Despite making less than half the money Shrek the Fourth made on its respective opening, Puss In Boots now holds the record for biggest Halloween weekend opening of all time, narrowly edging out Saw 3 on $33.6 million.

Paranormal Activity 3 was the lone flier of the horror movie flag this Halloween, its $18.5 million take putting it in second spot. The found-footage chiller was closely followed by Justin Timberlake’s sci-fi flick In Time, which made $12 million on its opening weekend.

The Footloose remake added a further $5.4 million to the pot in fourth place, whilst Johnny Depp endured a disappointing reaction to labour of love The Rum Diary, which opened to just $5 million. Shawn Levy’s Real Steel slumped somewhat to sixth place, only managing to add $4.7 million to its overall gross.

Meanwhile, the crash-bang-wallop extravaganza of The Three Musketeers continued to perform woefully below expectations, with a paltry $3.5 million weekend dragging its overall gross to $14.8 million. “Poor marketing”, cried star Milla Jovovich. “Poor film”, cried everyone else. That said, it was still more than was managed by some of the more cerebral fare on offer, with The Ides Of March and Moneyball bringing in just $2.7 and $2.4 million respectively.

Christian saga Courageous rounded off the top ten with a $1.8 million haul, completing a relatively slow weekend across the board. Next week sees a comedy face-off between Tower Heist and, er, A Very Harold & Kumar 3D Christmas. Look forward to that one…

article.title: Robert De Niro joins John Travolta for Killing Season
article.description:
Nicolas Cage and John Travolta won't face off again anytime soon: Robert De Niro has replaced Cage in action thriller Killing Season (formerly Shrapnel).

The film is based on a Black List script by Evan Daugherty (Snow White And The Huntsman), and sees two blokes engage a bit of cross-country cat-and-mouse action.

De Niro will play a military vet (as in veteran, not veterinarian), enjoying a relaxing break in a cabin in the Appalachian Mountains.

Travolta's playing a 'European' tourist, who befriends De Niro's character before revealing the fact he's a vengeful Serbian soldier out for blood. A one-on-one battle inevitably ensues.

While grizzled blokes in the wild premises are always going to snare our interest (we're unreasonably excited about Liam Neeson vs wolves in The Grey), this will always be tinged with disappointment concerning the inherent lack of Face/Off reunion for us.

Oh, and Mark Steven Johnson (Ghost Rider, When In Rome) is taking over directing duties from a departing John McTiernan. That doesn't bode well.

Travolta and Cage were also rumoured to be reuniting on Sea Trial too, though things have been very quiet on that front recently. Won't somebody just go ahead and greenlight Face/Off 2!

article.title: Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol gets a full trailer
article.description:
We've previously had a pretty tantalising glimpse of Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol in the form of a teaser, but a full trailer has finally landed online.

It basically expands on what we've already seen, giving a better sense of the story and putting the spectacular action sequences in context.

It's looking like Brad Bird has made a comfortable transition from animation to live action, and the plot seems satisfyingly simple: the IMF are set up, and have to go rogue to clear their name.

And let's be honest, we're all a litte more interested in this one now we know it'll give us a glimpse at a few minutes of The Dark Knight Rises (if you see it in 70mm IMAX at least).

Check out the full trailer right here:


Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol opens on 26 December 2011.

article.title: Justin Timberlake offered a key role in the Coen brothers' next
article.description:
Justin Timberlake's crossover from pop warbler to fully-fledged movie actor could be about to receive a credibility boost from the Coen brothers: they've offered him a major role in their new movie, Inside Llewyn Davis.

The film is set in New York's Greenwich Village during the '60s, and follows Oscar Isaac's title character, who's said to be loosely based on folk singer Dave Van Ronk.

If he signs on, JT is in line to play another folk singer named Jim, and he'll be married to Carey Mulligan's Jean.

It seems difficult to imagine Timberlake turning down the chance to work on such a talent-laden project, but the deal is only at the offer stage at the moment.

Timberlake's best work to date has been on The Social Network, but he's been taking on ever more prominent roles in sizeable movies, graduating to the lead in Friends With Benefits and In Time.

As with any Coen brothers movie, we'll be keeping a close eye on this one.

Inside Llewyn Davis is expected to open in 2013.

article.title: Robert Pattinson talks Breaking Dawn’s sex scenes
article.description:
When we sat down to talk about The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1 with star Robert Pattinson, we naturally brought attention to the elephant in the room: the hotly debated sex scenes.

Those marital relations have some pretty severe consequences too, with Bella becoming pregnant with a half vampire-half human child. Turns out we weren’t the only ones a little taken aback by this turn of events.

“When the final book came out, I was like ‘She’s not even thinking outside the box anymore. She’s broken the whole box!'” Pattinson told us.

“She went all out on the last one. It’s almost a different genre of movie.”

So, was Pattinson daunted by the prospect of the sex scenes? “It’s funny,” he added. “People talk about sex scenes in the book, but there aren’t actually any. It’s all in people’s imagination. They’re like ‘It’s so hardcore,’ but it always fades to black. It just shows bits of the aftermath.”

Not that that filmmakers will be taking that approach. “You have to show something!” Pattinson asserts.

“You can’t fade to black in the movie because people would go insane!

“It’s strange trying to do a singular event which everyone is expecting. At the end of the day, watching other people having sex is never going to be that spectacular. Hopefully it’ll be good. There’s so much hype. You’re like ‘God, I hope this lives up to it.’”

The saucy scenes are the least of Pattinson’s worries though, with the fang-to-placenta caesarean causing a much weightier concern. “It was horrible,” he admitted.

“Insanely graphic and the most nerve-racking thing about the whole shoot.”

The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn – Part 1 opens on 18 November 2011.

article.title: First official look at Ryan Gosling in The Place Beyond The Pines
article.description:
Ryan Gosling looks set to do for red leather jackets and peroxide blond locks what he did for scorpion jackets and toothpicks in Drive, if this official image from The Place Beyond The Pines is anything to go by.

The film, from Blue Valentine director Derek Cianfrance, sees Gosling revving up as a motorcycle stunt-rider turned bank robber.

Gosling is joined by a hell of a cast, including Bradley Cooper, Rose Byrne and Eva Mendes.

Here's the full image of Gosling, in all his garishly styled glory:



The official plot synopsis from production company Sierra Affinity goes as follows: "Luke (Gosling) is a professional motorcycle rider who turns to bank robberies to support his newborn son, but when he crosses paths with a rookie police officer (Cooper) their violent confrontation spirals into a tense generational fued.

"The Place Beyond The Pines is a rich dramatic thriller that traces the intersecting lives of fathers and sons, cops and robbers, heroes and villain."

Seeing as Cianfrance has previously said of Pines, "I’ve had people tell me they feel like its The Deer Hunter meets The Godfather", we're filing this one under 'Can't Frickin' Wait!'

The Place Beyond The Pines is in post-production, and is expected to open in 2013.

article.title: New on-set images from Dark Knight Rises' Trump Tower shoot
article.description:
Bruce Wayne's closest real-world approximation is apparently Donald Trump.

Well, that's if these new on-set shots featuring Trump Tower doubling for the Wayne Enterprises building are anything to go by.

Obviously spoiler-phobes should turn away now, but there's nothing too revealing on display here, just some nice scene-setting.

Close-up shots of Christian Bale show him looking more Bateman than Batman (it's all down to the hair), and Joseph Gordon-Levitt was also snapped on set.

Check out a selection of images, courtesy of Superhero Hype and Celebuzz, below:

article.title: First official images of Frankenweenie posted online
article.description: What do you do if you're a Tim Burton character and your dog dies? You reanimate it, of course - and the first official images of Victor Frankenstein doing just that to his pet Sparky have appeared online.  Burton told Entertainment Weekly, which published the images of the stop-motion animation Frankenweenie, that the film is about the enduring story of a child and his first pet.  “It just tries to keep that idea of a very, simple pure relationship. Mix that with the Frankenstein myth and it causes problems,” he said.   “It has its good side and repercussions,” Burton added. “Ultimately, we try to go with the slightly more positive aspects of keeping that relationship going.”   Burton lost his job at Disney for making a live-action short of the same material in 1984. However, that film helped open doors for his career as a director.  “I don’t know, they got freaked out or something, but they still allowed me to make the film. Even though I was frustrated about the release - or not release of it - it was still a great experience, and did a lot for me, so I couldn’t really complain,” Burton said.  Frankenweenie opens 5 October 2012.

article.title: Albert Finney joins Bond 23
article.description:
Just when we were all thinking that there was no way the Bond 23 (or should we say Skyfall?) cast could get any classier, Sam Mendes has gone and added Albert Finney to the line-up.

According to the Daily Mail's Baz Bamigboye (who has pretty good form with these Bond rumours), Finney recently joined the cast for a script reading at Pinewood Studios.

The English actor is said to be playing the sizeable role of "a Foreign Office mandarin with powers over the Secret Intelligence Service."

It won't be the first time Finney has crossed paths with a superspy, having appeared in The Bourne Ultimatum as key Treadstone figure Dr Albert Hirsch.

He joins what's possibly the best ever Bond cast, with Ralph Fiennes, Javier Bardem, Judi Dench, Naomie Harris, Ben Whishaw and Helen McCrory all signed on, and Daniel Craig returning as 007 for the third time.

With a set of thesps like that, it's no surprise Mendes is thought to be toning down the action in favour acting for his instalment.

Bond 23/Skyfall/Whatever… will open on 26 October 2012, which is less than one year away!

article.title: Star Trek 2 will use a different title
article.description: Sources close to the project have apparently revealed new information about J.J. Abrams Star Trek 2, including the fact that the sequel won't actually be called Star Trek 2.  The unnamed dirt-dishers claim the film will begin shooting in January but will use a different title.  Khan Strikes Back, perhaps?  Zoe Saldana, who plays Nyota Uhura, confirmed that the cast don't yet know where the sequel will boldly go.  “We still haven’t gotten a script yet,” she told Access Hollywood. “We’re very excited to read it and get back into space.”  “I’m really curious and I’m pretty sure that Zach is as well,” she said when asked if the romance between her character and Zachary Quinto’s Spock would continue.

article.title: Will Ferrell talks political comedy Southern Rivals
article.description:
We recently sat down with legendary Anchorman mirth merchant Will Ferrell, to chat about his career so far.

Talk lead to his upcoming political comedy, Southern Rivals, which will see him and Hangover breakout star Zach Galifianakis playing competing presidential candidates.

When we asked Ferrell about the intriguing project, he was more than happy to spill the beans, telling us:

“It’s basically the story of a small time congressional district in North Carolina, in the south, and I’m the incumbent candidate who’s about to run unopposed for my fifth term.

“There’s even mention of me being considered as a candidate for Vice President and that’s as high as my aspirations go. I just want to be Vice President and I have a wife who wants to be the Second Lady.

“We’re politically hungry, and I’m cruising along until I leave what I think is a message on my mistress’ voicemail but it’s really just a random family and it blows up in my face. I’m seen as vulnerable for the first time and the opposition decides to run a candidate against me and that’s Zach’s [Galifianakis] character.

“But you know, the movie is just a platform for us to illustrate how insane our political process has become. The crazy ad campaigns that exist now and the manipulations. We’re going to make it pretty farcical but not really that far from the truth.”

Ferrell is of course renowned for his spot-on take-off of George W Bush; will his Southern Rivals character be based on a real figure? “No, no, just kind of based on all the politicians nowadays and how no one really talks about any issues, just pays lip service to a bunch of things.”

Southern Rivals is expected to open in August 2012.

article.title: USC to restore and release John Carpenter's first Student film
article.description:
John Carpenter geeks will be glad to know we'll soon be able to trace him back to his cinematic roots. 

Captain Voyeur is John Carpenter's first film. It's an 8-minute, black and white short shot in 1969, which was unearthed in the archives of University of Southern California.

As it's the famed horror director’s first ever project it will be restored and released with the help from the National Film Preservation Foundation.

Captain Voyeur was written and directed for Carpenter's introductory film class.

Captain Voyeur has thematic and visual ties to Carpenter’s 1978 classic Halloween. One scene in particular is said to have a predominent link to Halloween:

“The voyeur puts on a pair of glasses over his mask, much in the manner that Michael Myers wore glasses over the bed sheet covering his head in the Halloween prologue.”

The man responsible for this amazing find, Dino Everett has said: "Captain Voyeur follows a man at a boring computer job who eyes a woman at work and follows her home. He dons a mask and attempts to kill her but is shot by his co-worker."

Once the film is restored we expect the film to be available on DVD release and online, so soon we can see where the legend first began.

article.title: Mary Elizabeth Winstead talks The Thing
article.description:
Total Film caught up with Mary Elizabeth Winstead on the set of The Thing, to find out what she’d be bringing to the prequel to John Carpenter’s 1982 classic.

Director Matthijs van Heijningen Jr told us that he wanted to differentiate this model from the earlier movie by bringing in a strong female character in the vein of Sigourney Weaver’s Ellen Ripley.

When we asked Winstead, who up to this point is probably best known for playing the object of Scott Pilgrim’s affection, about the comparison, she responded: “I definitely expect people to be bringing up the Ripley thing!”

She was keen to point out that she wouldn’t be playing a carbon copy of that iconic character though: “I’m playing a scientist. I’m not playing some badass chick.

“I kind of have to become strong throughout the film, and I kind of have to learn how to take care of myself and how to survive. I have to find strength.

“She’s sort of androgynous in a way, because her focus, and her passion in life, is her job. Finding a fossil in the ice is the utmost thing she could do. It’s a dream world for her, at first. And then it turns terrifying…”

So how was it being stuck in such a claustrophobic, testosterone-heavy environment? “I like being the only girl around here! It’s nice. I feel respected and one of the guys, which I don’t often get to experience.

“I feel honoured to be the first female in this story. It’s cool.”

The Thing opens on 2 December 2011.
